content: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Gynecologist An HPV love story Stephanie Georgopulos Blocked Unblock Follow Following Mar 11, 2014 For years, I had a crippling fear of the gynecologist. My mother began booking appointments for us both when I was sixteen, and I resisted every step of the way. First, I flat-out refused to get in the car. Then I figured I would go, but only if I didn’t have to get the full examination. The nurse never made it past second base. She could feel the boobs a bit, but the pants stayed on. “My period,” I’d lie, and she’d nod knowingly. Eventually, I learned menstruation is a great Get Out of Anything Free card. “Can’t go home with you tonight, got my period,” or, “Can’t wade in the urine-saturated Lazy River at Water World. My period. You know the drill.” At sixteen, I wasn’t comfortable with an older woman probing my nether regions with cold, sterile kitchen utensils. I was afraid of what she might find, what she might tell me. I was more afraid of what she might tell my mom. We had the same nurse practioner, so our appointments were always booked back to back. Her looming proximity discouraged me from being honest during exams, come hell or high blood clots. Do I smoke? No, of course not (yes). Have I had sex before? No (it’s been a few months, haven’t those incidents expired?). And of course, my go-to white lie, “No, I have my period; maybe you can examine me on my next visit. But in the meantime, can you hook a sister up with some birth control?” Then it’d be my mother’s turn. I imagined how they’d gossip about my sexual health behind that circular curtain, had I allowed the nurse to give me a full examination. “Let’s be real, Stephanie didn’t break her hymen riding horses, did she?” My mom, legs spread like she was a sanctuary for Thanksgiving stuffing, would snort and say, “That girl? Please. Give it to me straight, Dorothy.” (They’re on a first name basis, in my fantasy.) Dorothy would grin and say, “Oh, she’s definitely a little whore.” My mother would smile—her tact no match for her desire to discuss her eldest daughter’s sex life—and she’d casually reply, “Dorothy. Tell me something I don’t know.” They’d have a giggle at my expense. Moments later, my mother would emerge from behind the curtain of secrets and take me to McDonald’s. I treated each of these visits with contempt. I couldn’t bring myself to trust Dorothy. I knew she wasn’t worthy of my scorn; as a professional, she’d never report the shameful secrets she might discover while examining me to my mother. Besides, if I were to discriminate against anyone entering my vagina, there were more deserving candidates. But in my mind, every trip to the gynecologist was coupled with the potential of being found out. With every visit loomed the threat of introspection, the threat of holding myself accountable for my actions. I made it all the way to nineteen before my mother inquired about my sexual prowess. I sat in a director’s chair in my living room, natural light washing over every blemish on my skin. Her face was mere inches away from mine. She was customizing foundation for me, custom make-up being just one of many short-lived hobbies she dabbled in. She was always selling something, or going back to school, or, in this case, mixing an SPF 15 medium-tan foundation with a natural-tan foundation (a blend that would surely outmatch whatever drug store shit I’d been using to disguise impending acne). She kicked off the conversation by addressing Human Papillomavirus—or HPV, as it’s commonly called. Although this condition has existed since the beginning of time, a vaccine became available (and excessively marketed) in my late teens. HPV is sexually transmitted, hard to detect and, often, 100 percent symptom free. It’s worth noting that in some instances, untreated HPV can cause cancer. Seemingly overnight, Human Papillomavirus went from being an unknown enemy to the most common STD in the world, one that infects 5.5 million people a year. My mother, a former nurse and present-day sex enthusiast, expressed to me how important it was that I get vaccinated. I promised to look into it. She took this as an opportunity to delve deeper, explaining that the vaccination works best on virgins. “Are you a virgin?” There was no profound moment here, no heart to heart, no Wonder Years monologue about the passing of time and the unavoidable loss of childhood. I had been dating the same guy for a year, and the answer to her question was obvious. “What do you think, mom?” She smiled, still uncomfortably close to my face. “Well? Did you like it?” I assumed I’d hear some prepackaged manifesto about condoms, teenage pregnancy, waiting until the third date — anything but a request for my ill-informed opinions on the joys of sex. In that moment of shock, I exclaimed, “Mom!” She gave up, but she wasn’t defeated — her expression winked, “Momma knows, momma knows.” It was the first and last time we’d had a conversation like that. Had I heeded her advice to look into getting the HPV vaccine, I might still be one of those women who ranks the discomfort of gynecological visits somewhere between root canals and natural childbirth. Instead, I became a different kind of woman — a woman with HPV. That’s when I met Dr. Sifton. Through college, I’d continued to confine gynecologists to the northern regions of my body. But when I eventually loosened the reigns years later, I discovered my cervix was “irregular.” Not inflamed, not missing, just irregular. Like the heartbeat of someone who is seconds away from going into cardiac arrest. The school nurse referred me to an office close to campus, and I called immediately. The receptionist at the doctor’s office asked if I would mind a male doctor. The only thing I’d mind at that point was if my vagina fell out of my body and ceased to function, so I accepted the male doctor and had an appointment for a half-hour later. I was pleased to discover I would’ve allowed Dr. Sifton to check out my stock in an unprofessional setting. He was a real-life McDreamy, with deep brown eyes and a head of thick, black curls. With the aid of a nurse, he confirmed that indeed, my cervix was irregular. Then he asked if I was on the volleyball team. Apparently, the volleyball players in my college town were “irregular,” too. I had a colposcopy, which (painfully) ascertained that I had HPV, that I didn’t show signs of cancer (yet), and that I’d need to return regularly for check ups. I continued my doctor-patient relationship with Dr. Sifton for months. In that time, he regaled me with tales of his Greek wife, answered my hard-hitting questions about vibrators, and assured me I was neither the first—nor would I be the last—woman living with HPV. I went from loathing icy speculums and cotton swabs to greeting them with open legs, knowing each foreign object entering my vagina would bring me closer to healing. During class, my thoughts would often wander to Dr. Sifton, enumerating what questions I would address during my next appointment. It was in stark contrast with the way I’d behaved years earlier. I had gone from wearing a gynecologist-proof chastity belt to styling my paper gowns into a-line dresses during my visits. It took some time, but Dr. Sifton was the first man I trusted with my vagina. In the years following college, I longed for my months with Dr. Sifton. Graduating had left me without insurance and with even less money than I had as a student, which I didn’t think was possible. My time with Sifton was the last time I could waltz into a doctor’s office with an hour’s notice, the last time I didn’t have to spend half of my day in a waiting room. It was certainly the last time I could get screened for cancer without being verbally attacked by an abortion protester, which happened on my second visit to Planned Parenthood. Planned Parenthood is prone to all kinds of religious retirees who stand guard waiting to chastise anyone and everyone in the vicinity of the establishment. One morning, I had a showdown with a man who wore a sandwich board clad with images of partial-birth abortions. We volleyed back and forth for fifteen minutes, his argument being that a baby’s life was not worth free healthcare, my argument being that I was there to get re-screened for cancer. I told him if he’d like to invest in my personal well-being and provide me with healthcare, I’d be happy to take my business elsewhere. We screamed at each other, and no one won. That argument, while brief, had a lasting impact on me. Being reprimanded by someone you don’t know in the middle of a New York City street will have that effect, especially when you’re on your way to a biopsy. It made me reflect on the last year of my life, the disappointment I’d carried on my shoulders, the shame I’d inflicted on myself, the lonely months during which the thought of sharing my bed with another person made me recoil. Every potential relationship was tainted before it started because I’d chosen to stigmatize myself rather than understand that my situation was neither permanent nor uncommon. I was told time and again by doctors that physically, I’d be okay, but the mental and emotional anguish I put myself through was not under their control. And here was this stranger berating me, reminding me I was broken and uninsured, assuring me that if I cared about dead babies, I would not use Planned Parenthood’s services. I stared this man in the face, attempting to will his untimely death, but when it wouldn’t come, I went inside. What I wanted to do was snatch his sandwich board and beat him unconscious with it. What I wanted was for him to understand that my reproductive health couldn’t wait for affordable healthcare to pave the streets of Manhattan, that Planned Parenthood was the only option I had. I instead walked away with a terrifying lesson: that people who believe they have the right to dictate the personal choices of a stranger are not confined to the Bible Belt or documentaries as I had previously assumed. They’re everywhere, they’re inescapable. Here was a live one parading around on Bleecker Street, unwilling to consider the circumstances that brought me there in the first place and immune to feeling the smallest degree of empathy. It was soul crushing. Imagine my relief to walk inside those doors and feel welcome and accepted after that altercation. Dr. Sifton had conditioned me to trust gynecologists, and because of him, I was able to when I needed to most. When I needed to know that being proactive about my health was the right thing to do, no matter what mental, financial, and societal obstacles made it really fucking hard to get up in the morning, let alone get to a doctor’s appointment. And in the end, this new trust paid off. After a year of using Planned Parenthood’s services, I received papers in the mail confirming that my cervix had been restored to its regular state. Though I rarely saw the same doctor twice, I formed a bond with the Planned Parenthood staff that year. Everyone was informative and more than patient with my constant badgering. Picture a kid in the backseat of a car during a road trip. “Are we there yet?” “Not yet, we can’t perform another colopscopy for another few months.” “How about now? Does it look better?” “We can’t say yet.” As I paid little to nothing, as I showed up month after month for an update, they answered my inquiries with discipline and respect for what I imagine to be an unlivable salary. I took a liking to one doctor in particular, the one who’d read every book I dragged into her office and who played her low-fi tunes so quietly only she could hear. I imagined that, in a world where she was not the primary caregiver to my vagina, we would be friends. I imagined that when I had vaginal problems, I would turn to her first, as she was the authority. I would invite her over once every two months, pull my pants down, and say, “How about now? Are we there yet?” And, in a platonic sense, in a, “I’m your friend and I care about your reproductive organs” sort of way, she’d check out my stash and surmise, that yes, we are there.
title_html: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Gynecologist

How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Gynecologist

An HPV love story

Stephanie Georgopulos
Mar 11, 2014

For years, I had a crippling fear of the gynecologist. My mother began booking appointments for us both when I was sixteen, and I resisted every step of the way. First, I flat-out refused to get in the car. Then I figured I would go, but only if I didn’t have to get the full examination. The nurse never made it past second base. She could feel the boobs a bit, but the pants stayed on. “My period,” I’d lie, and she’d nod knowingly. Eventually, I learned menstruation is a great Get Out of Anything Free card. “Can’t go home with you tonight, got my period,” or, “Can’t wade in the urine-saturated Lazy River at Water World. My period. You know the drill.”

At sixteen, I wasn’t comfortable with an older woman probing my nether regions with cold, sterile kitchen utensils. I was afraid of what she might find, what she might tell me. I was more afraid of what she might tell my mom. We had the same nurse practioner, so our appointments were always booked back to back. Her looming proximity discouraged me from being honest during exams, come hell or high blood clots.

Do I smoke? No, of course not (yes). Have I had sex before? No (it’s been a few months, haven’t those incidents expired?). And of course, my go-to white lie, “No, I have my period; maybe you can examine me on my next visit. But in the meantime, can you hook a sister up with some birth control?”

Then it’d be my mother’s turn. I imagined how they’d gossip about my sexual health behind that circular curtain, had I allowed the nurse to give me a full examination. “Let’s be real, Stephanie didn’t break her hymen riding horses, did she?” My mom, legs spread like she was a sanctuary for Thanksgiving stuffing, would snort and say, “That girl? Please. Give it to me straight, Dorothy.” (They’re on a first name basis, in my fantasy.) Dorothy would grin and say, “Oh, she’s definitely a little whore.”

My mother would smile—her tact no match for her desire to discuss her eldest daughter’s sex life—and she’d casually reply, “Dorothy. Tell me something I don’t know.” They’d have a giggle at my expense. Moments later, my mother would emerge from behind the curtain of secrets and take me to McDonald’s.

I treated each of these visits with contempt. I couldn’t bring myself to trust Dorothy. I knew she wasn’t worthy of my scorn; as a professional, she’d never report the shameful secrets she might discover while examining me to my mother. Besides, if I were to discriminate against anyone entering my vagina, there were more deserving candidates. But in my mind, every trip to the gynecologist was coupled with the potential of being found out. With every visit loomed the threat of introspection, the threat of holding myself accountable for my actions.

I made it all the way to nineteen before my mother inquired about my sexual prowess. I sat in a director’s chair in my living room, natural light washing over every blemish on my skin. Her face was mere inches away from mine. She was customizing foundation for me, custom make-up being just one of many short-lived hobbies she dabbled in. She was always selling something, or going back to school, or, in this case, mixing an SPF 15 medium-tan foundation with a natural-tan foundation (a blend that would surely outmatch whatever drug store shit I’d been using to disguise impending acne).

She kicked off the conversation by addressing Human Papillomavirus—or HPV, as it’s commonly called. Although this condition has existed since the beginning of time, a vaccine became available (and excessively marketed) in my late teens. HPV is sexually transmitted, hard to detect and, often, 100 percent symptom free. It’s worth noting that in some instances, untreated HPV can cause cancer. Seemingly overnight, Human Papillomavirus went from being an unknown enemy to the most common STD in the world, one that infects 5.5 million people a year.

My mother, a former nurse and present-day sex enthusiast, expressed to me how important it was that I get vaccinated. I promised to look into it. She took this as an opportunity to delve deeper, explaining that the vaccination works best on virgins. “Are you a virgin?” There was no profound moment here, no heart to heart, no Wonder Years monologue about the passing of time and the unavoidable loss of childhood. I had been dating the same guy for a year, and the answer to her question was obvious. “What do you think, mom?” She smiled, still uncomfortably close to my face. “Well? Did you like it?”

I assumed I’d hear some prepackaged manifesto about condoms, teenage pregnancy, waiting until the third date — anything but a request for my ill-informed opinions on the joys of sex. In that moment of shock, I exclaimed, “Mom!” She gave up, but she wasn’t defeated — her expression winked, “Momma knows, momma knows.”

It was the first and last time we’d had a conversation like that. Had I heeded her advice to look into getting the HPV vaccine, I might still be one of those women who ranks the discomfort of gynecological visits somewhere between root canals and natural childbirth. Instead, I became a different kind of woman — a woman with HPV. That’s when I met Dr. Sifton.

Through college, I’d continued to confine gynecologists to the northern regions of my body. But when I eventually loosened the reigns years later, I discovered my cervix was “irregular.” Not inflamed, not missing, just irregular. Like the heartbeat of someone who is seconds away from going into cardiac arrest. The school nurse referred me to an office close to campus, and I called immediately. The receptionist at the doctor’s office asked if I would mind a male doctor. The only thing I’d mind at that point was if my vagina fell out of my body and ceased to function, so I accepted the male doctor and had an appointment for a half-hour later.

I was pleased to discover I would’ve allowed Dr. Sifton to check out my stock in an unprofessional setting. He was a real-life McDreamy, with deep brown eyes and a head of thick, black curls. With the aid of a nurse, he confirmed that indeed, my cervix was irregular. Then he asked if I was on the volleyball team. Apparently, the volleyball players in my college town were “irregular,” too.

I had a colposcopy, which (painfully) ascertained that I had HPV, that I didn’t show signs of cancer (yet), and that I’d need to return regularly for check ups. I continued my doctor-patient relationship with Dr. Sifton for months. In that time, he regaled me with tales of his Greek wife, answered my hard-hitting questions about vibrators, and assured me I was neither the first—nor would I be the last—woman living with HPV. I went from loathing icy speculums and cotton swabs to greeting them with open legs, knowing each foreign object entering my vagina would bring me closer to healing.

During class, my thoughts would often wander to Dr. Sifton, enumerating what questions I would address during my next appointment. It was in stark contrast with the way I’d behaved years earlier. I had gone from wearing a gynecologist-proof chastity belt to styling my paper gowns into a-line dresses during my visits. It took some time, but Dr. Sifton was the first man I trusted with my vagina.

In the years following college, I longed for my months with Dr. Sifton. Graduating had left me without insurance and with even less money than I had as a student, which I didn’t think was possible. My time with Sifton was the last time I could waltz into a doctor’s office with an hour’s notice, the last time I didn’t have to spend half of my day in a waiting room. It was certainly the last time I could get screened for cancer without being verbally attacked by an abortion protester, which happened on my second visit to Planned Parenthood.

Planned Parenthood is prone to all kinds of religious retirees who stand guard waiting to chastise anyone and everyone in the vicinity of the establishment. One morning, I had a showdown with a man who wore a sandwich board clad with images of partial-birth abortions. We volleyed back and forth for fifteen minutes, his argument being that a baby’s life was not worth free healthcare, my argument being that I was there to get re-screened for cancer. I told him if he’d like to invest in my personal well-being and provide me with healthcare, I’d be happy to take my business elsewhere. We screamed at each other, and no one won.

That argument, while brief, had a lasting impact on me. Being reprimanded by someone you don’t know in the middle of a New York City street will have that effect, especially when you’re on your way to a biopsy. It made me reflect on the last year of my life, the disappointment I’d carried on my shoulders, the shame I’d inflicted on myself, the lonely months during which the thought of sharing my bed with another person made me recoil. Every potential relationship was tainted before it started because I’d chosen to stigmatize myself rather than understand that my situation was neither permanent nor uncommon. I was told time and again by doctors that physically, I’d be okay, but the mental and emotional anguish I put myself through was not under their control. And here was this stranger berating me, reminding me I was broken and uninsured, assuring me that if I cared about dead babies, I would not use Planned Parenthood’s services. I stared this man in the face, attempting to will his untimely death, but when it wouldn’t come, I went inside.

What I wanted to do was snatch his sandwich board and beat him unconscious with it. What I wanted was for him to understand that my reproductive health couldn’t wait for affordable healthcare to pave the streets of Manhattan, that Planned Parenthood was the only option I had. I instead walked away with a terrifying lesson: that people who believe they have the right to dictate the personal choices of a stranger are not confined to the Bible Belt or documentaries as I had previously assumed. They’re everywhere, they’re inescapable. Here was a live one parading around on Bleecker Street, unwilling to consider the circumstances that brought me there in the first place and immune to feeling the smallest degree of empathy. It was soul crushing.

Imagine my relief to walk inside those doors and feel welcome and accepted after that altercation. Dr. Sifton had conditioned me to trust gynecologists, and because of him, I was able to when I needed to most. When I needed to know that being proactive about my health was the right thing to do, no matter what mental, financial, and societal obstacles made it really fucking hard to get up in the morning, let alone get to a doctor’s appointment. And in the end, this new trust paid off. After a year of using Planned Parenthood’s services, I received papers in the mail confirming that my cervix had been restored to its regular state.

Though I rarely saw the same doctor twice, I formed a bond with the Planned Parenthood staff that year. Everyone was informative and more than patient with my constant badgering. Picture a kid in the backseat of a car during a road trip. “Are we there yet?” “Not yet, we can’t perform another colopscopy for another few months.” “How about now? Does it look better?” “We can’t say yet.” As I paid little to nothing, as I showed up month after month for an update, they answered my inquiries with discipline and respect for what I imagine to be an unlivable salary.

I took a liking to one doctor in particular, the one who’d read every book I dragged into her office and who played her low-fi tunes so quietly only she could hear. I imagined that, in a world where she was not the primary caregiver to my vagina, we would be friends. I imagined that when I had vaginal problems, I would turn to her first, as she was the authority. I would invite her over once every two months, pull my pants down, and say, “How about now? Are we there yet?” And, in a platonic sense, in a, “I’m your friend and I care about your reproductive organs” sort of way, she’d check out my stash and surmise, that yes, we are there.

Thanks to Kate Lee.

title: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Gynecologist

An HPV love story

Stephanie Georgopulos
Mar 11, 2014

Planned Parenthood is prone to all kinds of religious retirees who stand guard waiting to chastise anyone and everyone in the vicinity of the establishment. One morning, I had a showdown with a man who wore a sandwich board clad with images of partial-birth abortions. We volleyed back and forth for fifteen minutes, his argument being that a baby’s life was not worth free healthcare, my argument being that I was there to get re-screened for cancer. I told him if he’d like to invest in my personal well-being and provide me with healthcare, I’d be happy to take my business elsewhere. We screamed at each other, and no one won.

That argument, while brief, had a lasting impact on me. Being reprimanded by someone you don’t know in the middle of a New York City street will have that effect, especially when you’re on your way to a biopsy. It made me reflect on the last year of my life, the disappointment I’d carried on my shoulders, the shame I’d inflicted on myself, the lonely months during which the thought of sharing my bed with another person made me recoil. Every potential relationship was tainted before it started because I’d chosen to stigmatize myself rather than understand that my situation was neither permanent nor uncommon. I was told time and again by doctors that physically, I’d be okay, but the mental and emotional anguish I put myself through was not under their control. And here was this stranger berating me, reminding me I was broken and uninsured, assuring me that if I cared about dead babies, I would not use Planned Parenthood’s services. I stared this man in the face, attempting to will his untimely death, but when it wouldn’t come, I went inside.

What I wanted to do was snatch his sandwich board and beat him unconscious with it. What I wanted was for him to understand that my reproductive health couldn’t wait for affordable healthcare to pave the streets of Manhattan, that Planned Parenthood was the only option I had. I instead walked away with a terrifying lesson: that people who believe they have the right to dictate the personal choices of a stranger are not confined to the Bible Belt or documentaries as I had previously assumed. They’re everywhere, they’re inescapable. Here was a live one parading around on Bleecker Street, unwilling to consider the circumstances that brought me there in the first place and immune to feeling the smallest degree of empathy. It was soul crushing.

Imagine my relief to walk inside those doors and feel welcome and accepted after that altercation. Dr. Sifton had conditioned me to trust gynecologists, and because of him, I was able to when I needed to most. When I needed to know that being proactive about my health was the right thing to do, no matter what mental, financial, and societal obstacles made it really fucking hard to get up in the morning, let alone get to a doctor’s appointment. And in the end, this new trust paid off. After a year of using Planned Parenthood’s services, I received papers in the mail confirming that my cervix had been restored to its regular state.

Though I rarely saw the same doctor twice, I formed a bond with the Planned Parenthood staff that year. Everyone was informative and more than patient with my constant badgering. Picture a kid in the backseat of a car during a road trip. “Are we there yet?” “Not yet, we can’t perform another colopscopy for another few months.” “How about now? Does it look better?” “We can’t say yet.” As I paid little to nothing, as I showed up month after month for an update, they answered my inquiries with discipline and respect for what I imagine to be an unlivable salary.

I took a liking to one doctor in particular, the one who’d read every book I dragged into her office and who played her low-fi tunes so quietly only she could hear. I imagined that, in a world where she was not the primary caregiver to my vagina, we would be friends. I imagined that when I had vaginal problems, I would turn to her first, as she was the authority. I would invite her over once every two months, pull my pants down, and say, “How about now? Are we there yet?” And, in a platonic sense, in a, “I’m your friend and I care about your reproductive organs” sort of way, she’d check out my stash and surmise, that yes, we are there.
